metadata.title: Pronator Teres Syndrome •Notify physician immediately on positive findings for complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), cervical radiculopathy, or DVT
anatomical location body part affected: Pronator teres (proximal volar forearm) causing compression of the median nerve
description: Pronator teres syndrome is a rare compressive neuropathy of the median nerve caused by compression from the pronator teres in the proximal forearm(9)

A diagnostic challenge, especially in mild cases.(2) Careful differential diagnosis is required because symptoms overlap with carpal tunnel syndrome, a much more common median nerve injury, as well as with other neuropathies in the upper extremity (e.g., anterior interosseous syndrome, brachial plexus neuritis)(9)
Research is lacking to guide treatment strategies

ICD-10 codes.G56.9: Unspecified mononeuropathy of upper limb (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special insurance agencies or legal issues have been identified regarding the reimbursement for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Paresthesias in the median nerve distribution
Symptoms initiated or aggravated by prolonged and/or repetitive wrist and forearm activities

Possible signs/symptoms –Sensory deficit in the radial three digits, the radial half of the fourth digit, and the palm –Grip strength weakness (usually mild) compared to the unaffected side –Pronator teres hypertrophy Causes, Pathogenesis, and Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: In postoperative cases, request instructions from a physician regarding precautions for mobilization and the expected outcome
Notify physician immediately on positive findings for complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), cervical radiculopathy, or DVT

causes: Repetitive gripping or forearm pronation (e.g., hammering, dishwashing, tennis) leadingto pronator teres hypertrophy(9)
Local trauma, schwannoma, and with renal dialysis in patients on anticoagulation therapy(9)
pathogenesis: The site of median nerve compression is usually between the two heads of the pronator muscle. In some cases thecompression may be at other sites, including the ligament of Struthers and bicipital aponeurosis (lacertus fibrosus) and thearcade of flexor digitorum superficialis(1,9)
The severity of median nerve injury and resulting symptoms depend on the degree and duration of the applied pressure
Pronator teres syndrome may be mistaken for carpal tunnel syndrome(9)
risk factors: Repetitive overuse of upper extremity with wrist pronated (activities listed under Causes )
Female sex: women are 4 times more likely to develop pronator teres syndrome than men(4)

Anatomical/congenital variants that may cause entrapment(1,9,11)–Presence of a fibrous band at the site where the median nerve passes between the two heads of the pronator muscle–Abnormally enlarged pronator muscle–Aponeurotic bridge of the flexor digitorum superficialis muscle–Thickening of the of the bicipital aponeurosis–Anomalous median artery

overall contraindications precautions: Symptoms of acute illness include fever, chills, night sweats, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which may disqualify the patient from physical therapy because exercising the involved limb is contraindicated

Older adult patients who may require multidisciplinary rehabilitation or special considerations for examination and treatment, such as those with mobility restrictions, cardiopulmonary disease, or diabetes reduced cognitive function secondary to dementia
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: In postoperative cases, request instructions from a physician regarding precautions for mobilization and the expected

contraindications precautions: Over an area of peripheral nerve regrowth
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
In the very young or very old

Do not place electrodes near -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs), phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads, areas with known peripheral vascular disease, areas with hemorrhage, areas with active osteomyelitis
Cardiovascular disease(e.g., uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heart rate)
Electrodes near compromised skin or neck/craniofacial regions in patients with a history of seizures or cerebrovascular accident
In pregnant women; near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen or history of spontaneous abortion
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronic devices
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Only those contraindications/precautions with regards to modalities applicable to this diagnosis are listed below
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use:(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain, tenderness, and paresthesias likely secondary to median nerve compression in the proximal forearm. Symptoms restrict usual activities
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS)(9) –Pronator teres syndrome may be present along with CTS -Researchers in Iran who conducted a study to determine the prevalence of pronator teres syndrome in a cohort of patients with CTS found that in a group of 148 patients with CTS, 8.8% had electrodiagnostically confirmed pronator teres syndrome and 18.2% had clinically confirmed pronator teres syndrome(8) -Authors of a retrospective study of a group of 344 cases found that within the cases 21 patients (6%) had combined CTS and pronator teres syndrome. Patients with isolated pronator teres syndrome had numbness at the thenar eminence but no nocturnal symptoms. In patients with nocturnal symptoms and thenar numbness, combined CTS and pronator teres syndrome should be suspected(10) Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome(9) Brachial plexopathy(9) Cervical radiculopathy(9) Thoracic outlet compression syndrome(9) Peripheral polyneuropathy(9) Overuse of forearm muscles(9)
prognosis: Nonoperative treatment (i.e., rest, activity modification, NSAIDs, injection) should be tried for at least 6 weeks before considering surgery

For cases requiring surgical intervention(9) –Good outcomes with return to full activities within 6 weeks with isolated pronator teres release –With surgery involving tendon transfers for weakness, increased therapy required and return to activities at 10 to 12 weeks
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer patients with continuing pain, tenderness, and/or pain-related  weakness to hand therapist or orthopedic surgeon for further evaluation or acupuncturist for chronic pain
treatment summary: Nonoperative strategies include rest/immobilization (splinting with elbow at 90°, slight forearm pronation, slight wrist flexion), NSAIDs, corticosteroid injection, activity modifications, modalities, massage, and tendon/nerve gliding exercises. Washington State Industrial Insurance Medical Advisory Committee (IIMAC) guidelines recommend that nonoperative treatment should be trialed for at least 6 weeks(5)

Postoperative treatment should follow the surgeon’s instructions or general guidelines(2) –0–7 days: splinting as prescribed, non-weight-bearing –7–10  days: remove sutures, discontinue splinting as prescribed, start gentle ROM exercises –4–6 weeks: begin strengthening exercises –Maintenance phase: the trial of return to full activities/sport . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain, tenderness, and paresthesias _ _ Limitation of activities _ postoperative healing phaseResolved symptoms _ _ Protect healing structuresAdaptive devices, physical agents, mechanical modalities, and activity modification _ Splinting, as prescribed. Apply RICE formula (i.e., rest, ice, compression, and elevation), including cryotherapeutic agents; restrict aggravating activities; NSAID for pain controlReduce treatment frequency as symptoms resolveProvide patient with simple instructions to manage pain and to protect healing structures at home during postoperative healing Postoperative edema Resolved edema Therapeutic modalities _ Trial of interferential electrical stimulation, although specific guidelines for pronator teres syndrome are not availableReduce treatment frequency as pain and edema resolveN/A Pain, tenderness, limitation of activities. Pain-restricted ROM and strengthRestore pain-free use of involved arm with normal range and strengthManual and therapeutic exercises _ Massage. Tendon and median nerve gliding exercises at the wrist.(5) ROM and strengthening exercises, as indicatedGradually progress the intensity and duration of exercises as the pain- free range improvesProvide patient with simple ROM, strengthening, and gliding exercises. Independent program of exercises .

maintenance or prevention: Ongoing therapeutic exercises may be necessary to maintain pain-free  use of the involved arm
Avoidance or modification of aggravating activities to prevent recurrence(9) Hammering Washing dishes Tennis Pouring drinks Carrying books Wringing out clothes
patient education: See “Nerve Compression Syndromes of the Hand” from Medscape at https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1285531-overview
See “Pronator Teres Syndrome” from Radiopaedia.org at https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pronator-teres-syndrome-2

See “Pronator Syndrome” from Orthobullets at https://www.orthobullets.com/hand/6020/pronator-syndrome Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
